* TLS
** TLS attacks, by jas
- types av crypto: stream, block, authenticated
- 3DES or AES can be run in CBC mode
- CBC needs padding to even block sizes
- TLS uses pkcs#5 padding
- padding attacks started in 2002 (vaudenay)
- demo in 2010 (rizzo and duong)

- padding oracle attacks guess the last padding byte 

- WTLS (woo, old stuff) returns "padding error" (instead of simply
  "encryption error"), in clear text, which makes an attack easy

- another solution would be to check the MAC regardless of padding
  errors

- yet another solution would be to first encrypt and then pad

- or just skip CBC mode

- lucky-13 exploits the timing side channel attack mentioned in RFC
  5246, 6.2.3.2:

   This leaves a small timing channel, since MAC
   performance depends to some extent on the size of the data fragment,
   but it is not believed to be large enough to be exploitable, due to
   the large block size of existing MACs and the small size of the
   timing signal.

- BEAST exploits that the IV used in TLS CBC mode is taken from the
  previous packet

- a solution is to send every second packet empty, to "reset" the IV

- CRIME uses the fact that different types of data are compressed
  differently

- the solution is to disable compression

- rc4 is an old stream cipher, really fast but considered broken (by
  crypto people -- encrypted data doesn't look random, which means
  broken) but still used by "everybody"

- salsa20 is a modern stream cipher by djb, it's fast (but still only
  half as fast of rc4) and built on a hash function

- concatenated hashes of (key, nonce, block number), where nonce and
  block number are 64 bit numbers and has a very low setup cost

- the stream is seekable -- you don't have to calculate byte/block of
  bytes n in order to produce n+1, which is good for things like DTLS
  (packet drop)

- a problem in TLS is that the protocol doesn't have room for an IV
  for stream ciphers

- CBC to stream? or change to AEAD (requires TLS 1.1)

** triple handshake attack
- unused writeup for radsecproxy client side
Radsecproxy client side is another matter. It seems like an OpenSSL
client supports RFC5746 "secure renegotiation" by default (given OpenSSL
version 0.9.8m and later). If this is correct and if the RadSec server
which radsecproxy connects to supports renegotiation, the connection
might be susceptible to the first attack described. The attacker has to
be able to make the server initiate renegotiation and the server must
accept initially unauthenticated clients. I don't know how likely that
might be but it sounds unlikely.

* unicode and character encoding
"Unicode, a misspelled unicorn"

Sigh. This is so painful! I've spent probably ten years ignoring the
question of character encoding as much as possible. I've always
thought that I could postpone the inevitable for yet some time. But I
guess this just has to come to an end at some point. Is now the time
when I finally will have to learn what a code point is? Please no! I'm
too young! (Actually, I'm not.)

How many layers are there? Is it even possible to count them? There's
something called Xorg (X11), and a window manager (wm). I ususally run
a program called xterm, in which a screen is often running. In screen,
there are normally numerous instances of bash and often more programs
(started by bash). Somewhere in here there are less known libraries
involved, like ncurses (or ncursesw?) and readline (reading ~/.inputrc
and caring about things like the meta key). And how does environment
variables like TERM and LANG influence all of this?

How can I find out which of all these components is messing with my
input this time? Or my output. And what is this UTF-8 thing that
people tend to endorse and how does that relate to animals like
"Unicode" and "wide character"?

And while we're at it, I just have to get this off my chest: What does
ASCII really mean? I mean really? Let me just mention "Latin1",
"ISO-8859-1", "locale" and "character set".

Let's start with something practical and do a quick test. Run this in
a terminal window (like xterm):

  python -c 'print u"\u00e4"'

Does it print a UnicodeEncodeError message or does it print the
character 'ä'? (That character is what some people call a latin small
letter a with diaeresis). If you see that funny looking character, an
'a' with two dots, skip ahead -- your xterm is clearly capable of some
cool stuff and you should celebrate some before continuing.

If your system is like mine, the Python error message says "ordinal
not in range(128)". Hmm, Python seems to be unhappy about printing a
character which "value" is higher than 128. Why is that?

As [py2-unicode] explains, u"\u00e4" means "code point" U+00E4. E4 is
in hexadecimal notation, equals 228 (base 10). This is clearly higher
than 128. Putting a couple of such code points after each other gives
you a "Unicode string". A sequence of code points has to be turned
into a sequence of bytes before it's sent off somewhere, like to
another program or to the disk. That's what's called "encoding".

Unicode is a character set which maps numbers to "glyphs" (i.e. shapes
that you can see on your screen).  UTF-8 is an encoding used by
Unicode.

ISO-8859-1, also known as Latin-1, is another encoding. Q: "Used by
Unicode"?

ASCII is a table with 128 code points (7 bits).

Latin-1 has 255 code points (8 bits).

In UTF-8, any Unicode code point can be represented. The encoding
takes into account backwards compatibility with ASCII and Latin1 as
well as space efficiency and the avoiding of bytes with the value
zero.

* 8 bit or Meta in xterm
In my bash running in xterm, M-b prints â, M-f prints æ and M-BS
prints ÿ. LANG is en_US.UTF-8. If I unset LANG, M-b, M-f and M-BS
work as intended (back one word, forward one word and delete one
word).

The xterm(1) man page has a lot of things to say about meta. It hints
that the "terminfo capabilities smm and rmm" might be used to change
xterm's terminal mode between 7-bit and 8-bit mode while running.

The terminfo(5) man page says that 'smm' has the variable string
"meta_on". An idea that overriding this setting from
/lib/terminfo/x/xterm in ~/.terminfo takes place.

But first, let's see if xxx eightBitMeta (class EightBitMeta) can be
set to 'false' instead. According to the xterm documentation, its
default value is 'locale' which means that "The key is modified only
if the locale uses eight-bit encoding".

Oh yes, setting the X resource 'XTerm*EightBitInput' to 'false' does
the trick. Edit or create ~/.Xresources and do xrdb -merge
~/.Xresources.

** Remote Branches (part of [[http://andyjeffries.co.uk/articles/25-tips-for-intermediate-git-users][25 Tips for Intermediate Git Users]])
9. Remote Branches

If you have a local branch that you’d like to appear on a remote server, you can push it up with one command:

$ git push origin twitter-experiment:refs/heads/twitter-experiment
# Where origin is our server name and twitter-experiment is the branch

If you want to delete a branch from the server (note the colon before the branch name):

$ git push origin :twitter-experiment

If you want to show the state of all remote branches you can view them like this:

$ git remote show origin

This may list some branches that used to exist on the server but now don’t exist. If this is the case you can easily remove them from your local checkout using:

$ git prune

Finally, if you have a remote branch that you want to track locally, the longhand way is:

$ git branch --track myfeature origin/myfeature
$ git checkout myfeature

However, newer versions of Git automatically set up tracking if you use the -b flag to checkout:

$ git checkout -b myfeature origin/myfeature
** rebase --onto
You want to rebase branch bug4711 on master in the origin repository.
Your changes to bug4711 should be put chronologically after the last
commit in master.  It shall look like you updated master and hacked
your things on top of it.

  git rebase --onto master --root bug4711
** rebasing and fixing up ("fixup!")
You want to rebase you current branch on master and do some fixup
(i.e., mark some commits as "fixup commits" for other earlier
commits).  If a reviewer wants to see the net result of your branch,
she can rebase --autosquash and the fixups will be squashed.  If she
wants to see the full history, she can simply look at your branch
without doing a rebase.

  git fetch origin
  git rebase -i origin/master  # mark commit doing the fixup with 'e' for edit
  git commit --amend --fixup <commit-to-fixup>
  git rebase --continue

** Getting rid of (unpushed) commits
F.ex. when sent as a patch by email and committed by someone else.
$ git reset --hard oirgin/master

Note that this works equally well for the scenario where you've pulled
something that you wouldn't want to push back, f.ex. when inspecting
someone elses clone of "your" repo by simply pulling it.
*** discussion with sebastian
<Sebastian> re twitter: git reset --hard origin/master  [14:47]
<Sebastian> that will reset your branch to the state after the clone  [14:48]
<Sebastian> if you want to keep a backup of your patch:
<Sebastian> git checkout -b backupbranch; git checkout master; git reset
	    --hard origin/master  [14:49]
<ln5> great, tnx.  thing is, i usually have a few patches unpushed.  i'd like
      to remove them as they get accepted upstream  [14:53]
<Sebastian> The best workflow typically is to make a new branch for every new
	    (logically separate) patch  [14:55]
<Sebastian> then you can just remove the branch once stuff got merged upstream
<Sebastian> and you never clutter your local master branch with commits that
	    aren't upstream
<Sebastian> the workflow goes like this:  [14:56]
<Sebastian> have a cloned repository somewhere, from earlier. Or clone a fresh
	    one. Then:
<ln5> yes, ic, good.  [14:57]
<ln5> that's better.
<Sebastian> git fetch origin; git checkout master; git merge origin/master
	    (this should be a fast-forward); git checkout -b <newbranchname>;
	    work work; git commit; git format-patch origin/master; send patch;
	    git checkout master
<ln5> in this case it's typically stupid small things like typos and small
      build errors and such

** Magit: Melting two commits
Place cursor on the (chronologically) _first_ commit of the two to
melt together.  Press 'r b' for beginning a rewriting operation.

In the "pending commits" list, place cursor on one of the commits to
melt together and press 'a'.
Place cursor on the second committ to melt together and press 'a'.
Press 'c' to commit.

Press 'r f' to finnish the rewrite.

** Weaknesses with SHA1
<A> B: collisions, someone can create fake/malicious objects with the
    same id

<A> gpg signing doesn't help afaics because the signatures are over
    the commit object, which merely references another tree object via
    its id

<A> linus' argument historically for not bothering to fix this was
    that "you can sign blah blah" but that completely misses the
    point, even with signatures you still have these weak references
    that can be attacked

** upgrading pkgsrc
which pkg_rolling-replace || ( cd /usr/pkgsrc/pkgtools/pkg_rolling-replace && make install clean )
# ftp://ftp.netbsd.org/pub/pkgsrc/current/pkgsrc.tar.bz2
# ftp://ftp.netbsd.org/pub/pkgsrc/current/pkgsrc.tar.bz2.SHA1
# For a stable pkgsrc, first do something similar to
#   export TAG='-2010Q3'
curl -O ftp://ftp.netbsd.org/pub/pkgsrc/stable/pkgsrc$TAG.tar.bz2.SHA1
curl -O ftp://ftp.netbsd.org/pub/pkgsrc/stable/pkgsrc$TAG.tar.bz2
sha1 pkgsrc$TAG.tar.bz2; cat pkgsrc$TAG.tar.bz2.SHA1
cd /usr; tar xzf /path/pkgsrc.tar.gz && rm /path/pkgsrc.tar.gz
cd pkgsrc; cvs update -dP	# only necessary when fetching stable pkgsrc
cd /usr/pkgsrc/pkgtools/pkg_rolling-replace && make && make update
nice pkg_rolling-replace -rsu -v

 ** FINAL NOTES **
1) The mailinglist directory have to be owned by the user running the 
mailserver (i.e. starting the binaries to work the list)
2) Run newaliases

This translates to:

sudo chown -R nobody:nogroup <listdir>
Add list address to transport and local-users, then do a postfix reload.

Configure list:
cd <listdir>/control && sudo touch modnonsubposts submod subonlyget subonlypost tocc
cd <listdir>/control && sudo echo <MODERATOR-EMAIL> > moderators
cd <listdir>/control && sudo echo \[<LIST-NAME>\] > prefix

If you're gonna mass-subscribe people to the list, wait with 'submod'
until after that has been done.

Subscribing people:
/usr/local/bin/mlmmj-sub -L /usr/local/mlmmj/lists.adb-centralen.se/LIST -a ADDRESS-TO-SUBSCRIBE

** inserting swedish characters
insert is a built-in function in `C source code'.

(insert &rest args)

Insert the arguments, either strings or characters, at point.
Point and before-insertion markers move forward to end up
 after the inserted text.
Any other markers at the point of insertion remain before the text.

If the current buffer is multibyte, unibyte strings are converted
to multibyte for insertion (see `string-make-multibyte').
If the current buffer is unibyte, multibyte strings are converted
to unibyte for insertion (see `string-make-unibyte').

When operating on binary data, it may be necessary to preserve the
original bytes of a unibyte string when inserting it into a multibyte
buffer; to accomplish this, apply `string-as-multibyte' to the string
and insert the result.

* Travel
There are three types of travelling.
1. Within Sweden
2. Not touching UK
3. To or through UK

Travelling withing Sweden requires backing up your ordinary
laptop. Going through customs means don't bring an easily owned
device, i.e. bring an x60 (or equivalent) and a Tails stick or
two. Going to or through the UK means don't bring any encrypted
data. This might be a good idea for some other destinations as well,
depending on circumstances. The US and Canada springs to mind.

*** using quilt for producing patches
# From the maint-guide:
sudo apt-get install quilt
echo 'alias dquilt="quilt --quiltrc=${HOME}/.quiltrc-dpkg"' >> ~/.bashrc
alias dquilt="quilt --quiltrc=${HOME}/.quiltrc-dpkg"
cat > ~/.quiltrc-dpkg << EOF
d=. ; while [ ! -d $d/debian -a `readlink -e $d` != / ]; do d=$d/..; done
if [ -d $d/debian ] && [ -z $QUILT_PATCHES ]; then
    # if in Debian packaging tree with unset $QUILT_PATCHES
    QUILT_PATCHES="debian/patches"
    QUILT_PATCH_OPTS="--reject-format=unified"
    QUILT_DIFF_ARGS="-p ab --no-timestamps --no-index --color=auto"
    QUILT_REFRESH_ARGS="-p ab --no-timestamps --no-index"
    QUILT_COLORS="diff_hdr=1;32:diff_add=1;34:diff_rem=1;31:diff_hunk=1;33:diff_ctx=35:diff_cctx=33"
    if ! [ -d $d/debian/patches ]; then mkdir $d/debian/patches; fi
fi
EOF

** starting a virtual network
$ sudo virsh net-start default
Network default started

virbr0 has inet 192.168.122.1/24. debian0 gets 192.168.122.13/24 over
DHCP (why 13?). /etc/hosts in the host machine points out debian0.
Packets from the VM comes in on vnet0 and goes to virbr0 IIRC. There are
ACCEPT rules in the FORWARD chain letting them out on whatever i/f has
default gateway (but no rules letting them reach the host machine, which
is great).

** hardware
*** Entry level GSM/GPRS Terminal CT63 E [[https://www.elfa.se/elfa3~se_sv/elfa/init.do?item%3D10-492-34&toc%3D0&q%3D10-492-34][at ELFA]][[https://www1.elfa.se/data1/wwwroot/assets/datasheets/CEP_Terminals_Overview_eng_tds.pdf][, Data sheet 1]], [[http://download.cepag.com/downloads_dokumente/terminals/CT63%2520E%2520Datasheet.pdf][Data sheet 2]]
5V-32V RJ11: [[https://www.elfa.se/elfa3~se_sv/elfa/init.do?init%3D2&shop%3DELFA_SE-SV&item%3D69-687-23&][12V at ELFA]]
FME antenna: https://www.elfa.se/elfa3~se_sv/elfa/init.do?init=2&shop=ELFA_SE-SV&item=78-002-79&
*** huawei E1750
** software
- gammu-smsd plus stuge's upcoming posixmq additions for receiving sms
  http://wammu.eu/docs/manual/contents.html
- http://git.stuge.se/mysql-posixmq.git
  http://peter.stuge.se/mysql-posixmq-and-sha256
  [[file:src/psgsm.py][file:~/src/psgsm.py]]  
  det där scriptet genererar AT-kommandot för att låsa upp en E1750, givet IMEI som parameter
  efter några misslyckade cardlock-kommandon går stickan lite i baklås
  så prova inte mer än en gång :)
  gammu-smsd stöder olika backends för att lagra meddelanden
  filer, databaser, o.s.v.
  problemet är att all data sparas rå
  d.v.s. om någon annan applikation vill använda den där datan så är de 
  helt beroende av gammus interna dataformat för dagen
  jag jobbade på att ändra det till att använda ett väldefinierat meddel
  andeformat mer eller mindre i klartext, och jag jobbade på en backend som använde POSIX Message Queues
  jag valde ett epost-likt meddelandeformat
  det är komplicerat att hantera alla möjliga fall
  gsm är en sån soppa
  bitar hit och bitar dit

*** Film, for playing on the LG
**** Your have a DVDR image
If you have a DVDR image ('ISO 9660 CD-ROM filesystem' according to
file(1)) of the size 4.4G, burn with 

  sudo burncd dvdrw file

**** You have a DivX3-encoded AVI file (.avi)
Use growisofs on DivX3-encoded AVI files for reading them on the LG.

You really want the file to match this:
Opening video decoder: [ffmpeg] FFmpeg's libavcodec codec family
Selected video codec: [ffdivx] vfm: ffmpeg (FFmpeg DivX ;-) (MS MPEG-4 v3))

Or, as reported by file(1):
file.divx3.avi: RIFF (little-endian) data, AVI, 624 x 352, 23.98 fps, video: DivX 3 Low-Motion, audio: MPEG-1 Layer 3 (stereo, 48000 Hz)

  # growisofs -Z /dev/cd0 -J -R file.divx.avi

If you use -M instead of -Z you append files to the DVD.
***** History of failure
Trying to burn dvd+rw.
Failing reading DVD on the LG when trying the following methods:
- burncd dvdrw file.xvid.avi
- burncd dvdrw file.divx.avi
- burncd dvdrw file.divx.mpg
Suggests formatting of DVD+RW.  Apparently not good at "highest" level.

- growisofs -Z /dev/cd0 -dvd-compat -J -R /u/tmp/The_IT_Crowd.01.divx.mpg
"No video file."  This is much better!
**** You have something else
Use gmencoder to encode in DivX3, a.k.a. msmpeg4 codec in libavcodec.
Use avi or mpeg header?  Trying avi.

** splitting a key
For backup purposes a copy of the secret primary and subkey has been
split into five shares.  Three shares are required to reassemble the
key.  The key is not passphrase protected.

The software used is libgfshare by Daniel Silverstone which is an
implementation of Shamir Secret Sharing over a Galois Field.  On Debian,
install the libgfshare-bin package.  Use gfcombine on a sufficient
number of shares to reproduce the original input (make sure the files
have the proper name (foo.<number>).

*** Big picture (Debian jessie, gpg-agent started manually)
- pcscd is the PC/SC Smart Card Daemon
  - run by root, as a normal service
- gpg-agent is the interface for both gpg2 and ssh
  - started from ~/.xsession
- scdaemon is how gpg2 talks to the card
  - started by gpg-agent

** netdb.h
struct addrinfo
{
  int ai_flags;			/* Input flags.  */
  int ai_family;		/* Protocol family for socket.  */
  int ai_socktype;		/* Socket type.  */
  int ai_protocol;		/* Protocol for socket.  */
  socklen_t ai_addrlen;		/* Length of socket address.  */
  struct sockaddr *ai_addr;	/* Socket address for socket.  */
  char *ai_canonname;		/* Canonical name for service location.  */
  struct addrinfo *ai_next;	/* Pointer to next in list.  */
  };
** bits/socket.h
#define	PF_INET		2	/* IP protocol family.  */
#define	PF_INET6	10	/* IP version 6.  */
#define	AF_INET		PF_INET
#define	AF_INET6	PF_INET6

   struct sockaddr_storage
   {
   __SOCKADDR_COMMON (ss_);	/* Address family, etc.  */
   __ss_aligntype __ss_align;	/* Force desired alignment.  */
   char __ss_padding[_SS_PADSIZE];
   };

** netinet/in.h
   /* Internet address.  */
   typedef uint32_t in_addr_t;
   struct in_addr
   {
   in_addr_t s_addr;
   };

   struct sockaddr_in
   {
   __SOCKADDR_COMMON (sin_);
   in_port_t sin_port;			/* Port number.  */
   struct in_addr sin_addr;		/* Internet address.  */

   /* Pad to size of `struct sockaddr'.  */
   unsigned char sin_zero[sizeof (struct sockaddr) -
   __SOCKADDR_COMMON_SIZE -
   sizeof (in_port_t) -
   sizeof (struct in_addr)];
   };

   struct sockaddr_in6
   {
   __SOCKADDR_COMMON (sin6_);
   in_port_t sin6_port;	/* Transport layer port # */
   uint32_t sin6_flowinfo;	/* IPv6 flow information */
   struct in6_addr sin6_addr;	/* IPv6 address */
   uint32_t sin6_scope_id;	/* IPv6 scope-id */
   };

** Rätten till anonymitet

Expressen publicerade nyligen en del av Researchgruppens arbete med
att koppla samman namn med pseudonymer på rasist-sajter som
Avpixlat. Vissa skribenter på sajterna viade sig vara etablerade
Sverigedemokrater.

Frågan är, har SD-politiker samma rätt till anonymitet som alla andra?

Ingen har /oinskränkt/ rätt till anonymitet. Alla har dock rätt att
uttrycka sig inom ramarna för yttrandefriheten [utan att riskera hot
och trackasserier?] och rätt till [ett privatliv].


Rätten till [ett privatliv] regleras i [grundlagen, var?],
[EU-konstitutionen] och [FN-stadgan]. Yttrandefriheten inskränks av
ett antal lagar som t.ex. hets mot folkgrupp och förtal
[korrekt?].


Man kan vara för yttrandefrihet och samtidigt glädjas åt att affischer
med rasisiska budskap rivs ner på stan. Jag vet för jag är nämligen
sådan själv.

Man kan fråga sig själv om man skulle ha publicerat namnen bakom
pseudonymerna på rasist-forumen om man hade haft chansen. Jag vet
inte hur jag hade gjort. Att avslöja

* Kerberos
  213.115.13.24 resolvs to smtp.nordberg.se backwards.  This poses some
  trouble for OpenSSH clients (on some platforms, i.e. Debian package
  "openssh-client 1:4.7p1-8ubuntu1.2").

  With host/smtp.nordberg.se@NORDBERG.SE in /etc/krb5.keytab (and
  /etc/srvtab) and 

  GSSAPIStrictAcceptorCheck no

  in sshd_config.

  With strict acceptor check you'll have this, server side:

encrypted [[gnus:nnimap%2Badbc:INBOX#56CCE081.1070703@binary.to][Email from John Van de Meulebrouck Brendgard: Angående touch på yubikey]]

Jag har låtit undersöka om jag kan reproducera problemen jag nämnde att
jag hade med https://gist.github.com/a-dma/797e4fa2ac4b5c9024ccDet verkar dock lite svårt för den nyare som du fick fungerade utan
problem för mig att sätta touch på. Den verkar även ha en nyare version
av firmwaren än vad jag har testat förut:
gpg-connect-agent --hex "scd apdu 00 f1 00 00" /bye
D[0000]  04 02 08 90 00

Medan min vanliga produktionsnykel har:
gpg-connect-agent --hex "scd apdu 00 f1 00 00" /bye
D[0000]  04 02 07 90 00

Jag testade därefter om problemen kvarstår på den äldre versionen och
det gjorde de tills det att jag återställde firmwaren - då gick det på
första försöket.

Oavsett om det går eller ej så kan man "autentisera sig" genom att byta
admin lösenord med gpg2 --card-edit -> admin -> passwd -> "3 - change
Admin PIN" (går att sätta till samma om man vill) och modifiera skriptet
så att det inte försöker autentisera dig (eftersom du redan har gjort
det), alternativt ta ut godbitarna såsom t ex:
Sätt touch på sig:
gpg-connect-agent --hex "scd apdu 00 da 00 D6 02 01 20" /bye

Sätt touch på dec:
gpg-connect-agent --hex "scd apdu 00 da 00 D7 02 01 20" /bye

Sätt touch på aut:
gpg-connect-agent --hex "scd apdu 00 da 00 D8 02 01 20" /bye

Jag har satt fixed touch (02 istället för 01 i kommandona ovan) på sig
och dec eftersom jag inte vill att någon ska kunna ta bort kravet på
touch för dessa även om denne någon sniffat mitt admin-lösenord.

Quick guide on how to get started using SSH keys on a Debian system
(based on
https://github.com/SUNET/eduid-docs/blob/master/token-setup.mkd):

    sudo apt-get install gnupg2 scdaemon

    cat >> $GNUPGHOME/gpg-agent.conf <<EOF
    scdaemon-program /usr/lib/gnupg2/scdaemon
    enable-ssh-support
    write-env-file "$GNUPGHOME/gpg-agent-info-$(hostname)"
    EOF

    cat >> $HOME/.profile <<EOF
    if [ -f "${GNUPGHOME}/gpg-agent-info-$(hostname)" ]; then
        . "${GNUPGHOME}/gpg-agent-info-$(hostname)"
        export GPG_AGENT_INFO
        export SSH_AUTH_SOCK
        export SSH_AGENT_PID
    fi
    GPG_TTY=$(tty); export GPG_TTY
    EOF

    ykpersonalize -m82		# requires yuibkey to be inserted

**** status STAT
     [[file:/u/src/ezbounce/src/conn.cc::char%20conn%20mkstat%20char%20str_stat%20const][file:/u/src/ezbounce/src/conn.cc::char conn mkstat char str_stat const]]
     char * conn::mkstat(char * str_stat) const
     {
     int z = 0;
     if ((stat & NICKED) && (stat & USERED))  
     str_stat[z++] = 'r';
     if (stat & LOGGED_IN)   str_stat[z++] = 'L';
     if (stat & ADMIN)    	str_stat[z++] = 'a';
     if (stat & BOUNCED)    	str_stat[z++] = 'b';
     if (stat & CONNECTING) 	str_stat[z++] = 'c';
     if (stat & DETACHED)   	str_stat[z++] = 'd';
     if (stat & RECONNECTING) str_stat[z++] = 'E';
     if (stat & REGISTERING) str_stat[z++] = 'w';        /* (waiting) */
     if (is_dead()) {
     strcpy(str_stat, "(zombie)");
     z = 8;
     }
     str_stat[z] = 0;

     return str_stat;
     }

** banning and kicking on OFTC
http://www.oftc.net/ChannelModes/
http://www.oftc.net/UserModes/

Example, muting a user:
/msg chanserv op #tor-dev ln5
/mode #tor-dev +q <nick>!~<name>@<host>

Use `+b' to ban.

Or use AKICK in chanserv, I guess.

Example of how to list akick and quiet:
/query ChanServ akick #nottor list
/query ChanServ quiet #nottor list

Example banning:
*** ChanServ (services@services.oftc.net) has changed mode for #tor-project to      
    +o weasel

    to +b *!*Moev@*.tor-irc.dnsbl.oftc.net

** certs
1. Create a cert
   cd .priv
   rm -r demoCA
   ./mkcert ln5
   Common Name (e.g. server FQDN or YOUR name) []:ln5
2. Make ERC use it
3. Tell Nickserv to accept it
*** [linus@proj ~]$ cat mkcert.sh
#! /bin/sh

[ -d demoCA ] || { mkdir -p demoCA/private; mkdir demoCA/newcerts; echo 01 > demoCA/serial; touch demoCA/index.txt; }

openssl req -newkey rsa:2048 -nodes -keyout $1.key -out $1.req
chmod 600 $1.key
openssl ca -selfsign -keyfile $1.key -in $1.req -extensions v3_ca -out $1.crt
rm $1.req

openssl x509 -fingerprint -sha1 -noout -in $1.crt
openssl x509 -fingerprint -sha256 -noout -in $1.crt

* DNS
** DNSSEC
ns.adb-centralen.se uses knot for DNSSEC.

Two handy scripts for creating ZSK and KSK for a zone and getting DS
for a zone:

[root@ns /usr/local/etc/knot]# cat mkdnsseckeys.sh
#! /bin/sh

ZONE=$1
OUTDIR=/var/db/knot/keys

dnssec-keygen -K $OUTDIR -3 -a RSASHA256 -b 2048 $ZONE
dnssec-keygen -K $OUTDIR -3 -a RSASHA256 -b 2048 -f KSK $ZONE

chmod g+r ${OUTDIR}/K${ZONE}*.key
chmod g+r ${OUTDIR}/K${ZONE}*.private
[root@ns /usr/local/etc/knot]# cat ./getds.sh
#! /bin/sh

ZONE=$1

dig @193.10.5.87 dnskey $ZONE | dnssec-dsfromkey -1 -f - $ZONE
dig @193.10.5.87 dnskey $ZONE | dnssec-dsfromkey -2 -f - $ZONE
[root@ns /usr/local/etc/knot]# 

When adding DS to parent zone, use digest type 2 (SHA256):

[root@ns /usr/local/etc/knot]# ./getds.sh adb-centralen.se
adb-centralen.se. IN DS 3787 8 1 A58AC95664AC1DD9168F31E80F00F8EA49DCB465
adb-centralen.se. IN DS 3787 8 2 AAD386D929CB8432EA2E365C1872EA779F488C46C48B5F2E87859FF5B8DE31D6

In this example, the keytag is 3787, the algorithm is 8 (RSA/SHA-256)
and the digest type is 2 (SHA-256).

**** ripe-537 -- PI request
     http://www.ripe.net/ripe/docs/ripe-537
     Supporting Notes for the Provider Independent (PI) Assignment Request Form

#[GENERAL INFORMATION]#
     %
     % Please add your RegID.

     request-type: pi-ipv4
     form-version: 1.3
     x-ncc-regid: nl.bluelight

     Please do not change the value of the "request-type:" and "form-version:" fields.

     Enter your Registry Identifier (RegID) in the "x-ncc-regid:" field. RegIDs have the following format:
     <country code>.<name>. If you do not know your RegID, please contact ncc@ripe.net.

     Address Space User

#[ADDRESS SPACE USER]#
     %
     % Who will use the requested address space?

     legal-organisation-name: North SantaBank 
     organisation-location: Santa City, NN
     website-if-available: http://www.nsb.nn

     % Is this request being sent by a sponsoring LIR on behalf of 
     % an End User? (Yes/No)

     end-user-of-sponsoring-lir: Yes

     % If yes, please confirm that the "End User Assignment Agreement" 
     % contains all of the elements listed in paragraph 2.0 of "Contractual
     % Requirements for Provider Independent Resource Holders in the 
     % RIPE NCC Service Region".(Yes/No)

     confirmation: Yes

     % Does this End User already have address space that can be used for 
     % this assignment? (Yes/No)

     space-available:  No

     Enter the legal name and primary location of the organisation that will use this PI address space in
     the "legal-organisation-name" and "organisation-location" fields. If this End User has a website,
     enter the URL in the "website-if-available" field. Otherwise, enter "none" in this field.

     If you are an LIR sending this request on behalf of an End User, you should answer "Yes" in the
     "end-user-of-sponsoring-lir" field.

     If you answered "Yes" you should also confirm that all of the elements of paragraph 2.0 of
     "Contractual Requirements for Provider Independent Resource Holders in the RIPE NCC Service Region"
     are listed in the 'End User Assignment Agreement' that is signed by the End User and the sponsoring
     LIR. PI assignments can only be made to End Users if there is a signed 'End User Assignment
     Agreement' between the sponsoring LIR and the End User.

     You can find an example agreement online:
     http://www.ripe.net/membership/lir-end-user-agreement.html

     You can send us an agreement in your local language or use the English version.

     If this request is sent by a Direct Assignment User, you answer "No" to the above two questions.
     Direct Assignment Users have already signed an 'End User Assignment Agreement' with the RIPE NCC. If
     the request is for an LIR, you should also answer with "No".

     If there is any address space assigned to this End User that is not in use, indicate this in the
     "space-available" field. If you answer "yes", you can explain why the End User needs another
     assignment of address space in the "Network Description" section.

      

     Initial Information

#[INITIAL INFORMATION]#
     %

     % Why is PI address space required rather than PA address
     % space? 

     why-pi: North SantaBank will be multihomed. 
     We cannot use PA address space because our uplinks do not 
     allow their address space to be announced by other Autonomous Systems.

     % Is the End User requesting extra address space for routing
     % and/or administrative reasons? (Yes/No)

     routing-reasons: No. 

     % Have you made the End User aware of the consequences and
     % disadvantages of PI address space? (Yes/No)

     confirmation: Yes.

     In the "why-pi:" field, explain why PA address space cannot be used for this assignment. Remember
     that you should encourage the use of PA address space where possible.

     The RIPE NCC will assign additional IPv4 addresses to an End User in order to make the assignment
     size a multiple of a /24 if the End User demonstrates the intent to announce this address space for
     the purpose of multihoming to two or more Autonomous Systems (AS) which the End User does not own or
     control. Cumulatively, no more than 255 additional IPv4 addresses may be assigned to any particular
     End User for the purposes outlined above. You can state whether you are requesting more address space
     than needed in the "routing-reasons:" field.

     You must ensure that the End User understands and accepts that PI address space may be more difficult
     or more expensive to route than PA address space and then confirm this in the "confirmation:" field.
     You can find more details on the consequences and disadvantages of PI address space in the document
     "IPv4 Address Allocation and Assignment Policy for the RIPE NCC Service Region".

     Addressing Plan

#[ADDRESSING PLAN]#
     % As of 1 January 2010 assignments are for a period of up to 12 months.
     % As of 1 July 2010 assignments are for a period of up to 9 months.
     % As of 1 January 2011 assignments are for a period of up to 6 months.
     % As of 1 July 2011 assignments are for a period of up to 3 months.

     %
     % How will the End User use this address space?
     %

     %       Subnet       Immediate    Intermediate  Entire      Purpose
     %       size (/nn)   Requirement  Requirement   Period
     subnet: /26             32            64          64        Employee VPN Access
     subnet: /26             18            34          64        Financial Services
     subnet: /26             22            30          60        Workstations
     subnet: /27             11            15          28        Public Services
     subnet: /27              7            18          30        Operations
     subnet: /24            176           192         240        Branch Offices
     totals: /23            266           353         486

     number-of-subnets: 6

     % Will the End User return any address space?

     address-space-returned: 85.118.187/24 to nl.bluelight in 3 months

     The addressing plan shows how the End User will use the requested address space.

     You can repeat the "subnet" row as many times as needed. Delete any empty "subnet" fields before you
     send the request.

     In the "Subnet size (/nn)" column, enter a slash notation prefix for each subnet. Each entry should
     be large enough to contain the number of addresses needed for that subnet over the next time period.

     In order to demonstrate the predicted growth of your network, you must provide an estimate of the
     address space you will require over three distinct periods: Immediate, Intermediate and the Entire
     period. Your estimates should include interfaces used for hosts, routers, gateways, terminal
     concentrators and any other machines requiring one or more network interfaces. These columns can
     either contain numbers (for example, 128) or slash notation prefixes (for example, /25). Multiple
     slash notation prefixes must be separated by comma(s) with no blank spaces (for example, /25,/27).
     Starting on 1 January 2010, a gradual reduction in the assignment period will be applied. As the
     assignment period changes, so to will the information required:

     Up to 30 June 2010, assignments are for a period of up to 12 months. Therefore, your request should
     reflect your immediate requirements, predicted requirements for the coming 6 months, and predicted
     requirements for the coming 12 months.

     As of 1 July 2010, assignments are for a period of up to 9 months. Your request should reflect your
     immediate requirements, predicted requirements for the coming 6 months, and predicted requirements
     for
     the coming 9 months.

     As of 1 January 2011, assignments are for period of up to 6 months. Your request should reflect your
     immediate requirements, predicted requirements for the coming 3 months, and predicted requirements
     for
     the coming 6 months.

     As of 1 July 2011, assignments are for a period of up to 3 months. Your request should reflect your
     immediate requirements, predicted requirements for the coming 2 months, and predicted requirements
     for the coming 3 months.

     In the "Purpose" column, write a short description of each subnet. If needed, you can write a more
     detailed description in the "Network Description" section at the end of this form.

     In the "totals" row, add the totals of each column. The total of the "Subnet size (/nn)" column
     should be the total amount of address space you are requesting for this assignment.

     In the "number-of-subnets" field, enter the total number of subnets listed in the addressing plan.

     If there is any address space assigned to the End User that they will return, list each prefix in
     separate "address-space-returned" fields. The expected time for renumbering is three months. You can
     use the following syntax: <x.x.x.x/xx> to <which LIR/ISP> in <time period> for this field.

     Equipment Description

#[EQUIPMENT DESCRIPTION]#
     %
     % What equipment will be used and how will it use the requested
     % address space?

     equipment-name: Core switches
     manufacturer-name: Cisco
     model-number: 25xx
     other-data: 3 units

     equipment-name: Servers
     manufacturer-name: HP
     model-number: various
     other-data: 40 units

     equipment-name: Firewalls
     manufacturer-name: Cisco
     model-number: PIX 515 E
     other-data: 2 units, 8 IP addresses

     equipment-name: Workstations
     manufacturer-name: Dell
     model-number: GX150
     other-data: 22 units, 1 IP address each

     equipment-name: Routers
     manufacturer-name: Cisco
     model-number: 3825
     other-data: 2 units

     equipment-name: Routers
     manufacturer-name: Cisco
     model-number: AS5300
     other-data: 1 unit, 32 ports

     The equipment description will help us to understand the requirements listed in the addressing plan
     and can be repeated as many times as needed. Leave an empty line before each new "equipment-name"
     field.

     In the "equipment-name" field, enter the type of equipment requiring address space from this
     assignment.

     Enter the vendor name and model number for the piece of equipment in the "manufacturer-name" and
     "model-number" fields.

     If you have any more information about how this piece of equipment will use the requested address
     space, add this in the "other-data" field.

     Network Description

#[NETWORK DESCRIPTION]#
     %
     % Please add more information if you think it will help us understand
     % this request.

     We have 11 branches across Santa City linked by corporate fibre
     channels. We will assign a /28 subnet for each branch. Each branch
     will have SMTP, WWW, file server, e-banking and dial-up pool.

     Public Internet Services: SMTP (2 IP addresses), WWW (6 IP addresses,
     2 servers), FTP (1 IP address), DNS (2 IP addresses) Financial
     Services: 6 servers, 3 IP addresses each.  Operations network:
     Security, Monitoring, VPN, Proxy, DNS

     You can use this space for additional information that you think will be helpful for us (RIPE NCC)
     when we evaluate your request. A clearer understanding of the network and its addressing needs can
     help us to evaluate your request more quickly.

     Supporting Documentation

#[SUPPORTING DOCUMENTATION]#
     %
     % If this request is being sent by a sponsoring LIR on behalf of
     % an End User, please attach a copy of the signed "End User Assignment
     % Agreement" and the company registration papers of the End User.
     % You can also attach a network diagram or other supporting
     % documentation.
     %
     % Have you attached any files/documents to this request? (Yes/No)

     file-attached: Yes

     For each PI assignment that is requested through a sponsoring LIR for an End User, we need to receive
     a copy of 'End User Assignment Agreement' and the company registration papers of the End User.

     If this request is for an LIR or a "Direct Assignment User", you do not have to attach a copy of 'End
     User Assignment Agreement' and company registration papers.

     A network diagram (topology map) can help us to understand the set-up of the network and its
     addressing needs.

     Database Template(s)

#[DATABASE TEMPLATE(S)]#
     %
     % Please complete all of the fields below.

     inetnum:
     netname: NSB-NET
     descr: North SantaBank
     country: NN
     org: ORG-NS31-RIPE
     admin-c: ACM2-RIPE
     tech-c: HOHO1-RIPE
     status: ASSIGNED PI
     mnt-by: RIPE-NCC-END-MNT
     mnt-lower: RIPE-NCC-END-MNT
     mnt-by: SANTA-MNT
     mnt-routes: SANTA-MNT
     mnt-domains: SANTA-MNT
     changed: hostmaster@ripe.net
     source: RIPE

     Leave the "inetnum" field empty as we will choose the address range.

     The "netname" should be a short and descriptive name for the network and should reflect the
     organisation name of the End User.

     Enter the End User's organisation name in the "descr" field.

     Use the ISO country code of the End User's location in the "country" field. If the End User is
     multi-national, repeat the "country" field as many times as needed. Alternatively, you can use EU or
     ZZ if you do not wish to show the End User's location in the inetnum object.

     Enter the org-ID of the End User's organisation object in the "org" field.

     The nic-handle of the role or person object in the "admin-c" field should reflect someone who is
     administratively responsible for the network.

     The nic-handle of the role or person object in the "tech-c" field should reflect someone who has
     technical knowledge of the network.

     The "status" field must be ASSIGNED PI.

     The "mnt-by" and "mnt-lower" fields must contain RIPE-NCC-END-MNT. You can put the LIR's or End
     User's maintainers in separate "mnt-by", "mnt-routes" and "mnt-domains" fields.

     The "mnt-by" field shows which maintainer authenticates object updates. The "mnt-routes" and
     "mnt-domains" fields show which maintainers authenticate the creation of route and domain objects.

     The RIPE Database must contain all of the objects that you use.

     The "changed" field must be hostmaster@ripe.net.

     The "source" field must be RIPE.

     End of Request

     Best Regards,

     Jan Janssen, Bluelight Admin

** Disk encryption with geli
dd if=/dev/random of=/root/ad4s1f.key bs=64 count=1
geli init -K /root/ad4s1f.key /dev/ad4s1f
[Enter new passphrase:]
[Reenter new passphrase:]
geli attach -k /root/ad4s1f.key /dev/ad4s1f
dd if=/dev/random of=/dev/ad4s1f.eli
*** creating an encrypted usb stick
  geli init -a HMAC/SHA256 /dev/da0a
  geli attach /dev/da0a
  dd if=/dev/random of=/dev/da0a.eli bs=1m
  newfs /dev/da0a.eli 
  mount /dev/da0a.eli /us
  umount /us
  geli detach da0a
*** changing passphrase for attached /dev/ad4s1f
geli setkey -K /root/ad4s1f.key /dev/ad4s1f
geli backup /dev/ad4s1f /var/backups/ad4s1f.eli
*** encrypted root and swap partitions
- installing 9.0-release, based on http://www.wanda25.de/geli2.html

- put FreeBSD-9.0-RELEASE-amd64-memstick.img on a USB stick and boot
  from it
- create two slices (ada0s1 and ada0s2) let the first one be 1G and
  the second one have the rest of the disk
- label the first slice with a single partition and mount it on /
- install kernel and nothing more

- get a shell and prepare the second partition, the one to be
  encrypted, from there:
  dd if=/dev/random of=/dev/ada0s2 bs=1m  # will take some 1-2h per GB
  kldload geom_eli
  geli init -b -l 256 /dev/ada0s2
  geli attach /dev/ada0s2
  bsdlabel -w /dev/ada0s2.eli
  bsdlabel -e /dev/ada0s2.eli
    a: 1g 16 4.2BSD # /
    b: 4g * swap
    c: <don't change>
    d: 4g * 4.2BSD # /var
    e: 2g * 4.2BSD # /tmp
    f: 10g * 4.2BSD # /home
    g: * * 4.2BSD /usr

  for f in a d e f g; do newfs /dev/ada0s2$f && tunefs -l enable /dev/ada0s2$f; done
  mkdir /mnt/boot /mnt/crypt
  mount /dev/ada0s1 /mnt/boot
  mount /dev/ada0s2.elia /mnt/crypt
  mkdir /mnt/crypt/var /mnt/crypt/tmp /mnt/crypt/home /mnt/crypt/usr
  mount /dev/ada0s2.elid /mnt/crypt/var
  cp -Rpv /var/backups /mnt/crypt/var/   # save the geli metadata backup for ada0s2
  mount /dev/ada0s2.elie /mnt/crypt/tmp
  mount /dev/ada0s2.elif /mnt/crypt/home
  mount /dev/ada0s2.elig /mnt/crypt/usr

- alternatively, with gpart
  dd if=/dev/random of=/dev/ada0 bs=1m          # will take some time, like 1-2h per GB
  gpart create -s GPT ada0
  gpart bootcode -b /boot/pmbr ada0
  gpart add -b 34 -s 128 -t freebsd-boot ada0	# 64 KB
  gpart bootcode -p /boot/gptboot -i 1 ada0
  gpart add -s 1G -t freebsd-ufs ada0 # ada0p2 -- 1G unencrypted UFS to boot from
  gpart add -t freebsd-ufs ada0       # ada0p3 -- the rest for an encrypted partition

  dd if=/dev/random of=/dev/ada0p3 bs=1m  # will take some 1-2h per GB
  kldload geom_eli
  mount -u /   # need /var to be writable
  geli init -b -l 256 /dev/ada0p3
  geli attach /dev/ada0p3

  <see above for bsdlabel, newfs, mkdir, mount, cp -- use /dev/ada0p3.eli>
  
- install
  tar xpzf /usr/freebsd-dist/kernel.txz -C /mnt/crypt
  tar xpzf /usr/freebsd-dist/base.txz -C /mnt/crypt
  tar xpzf /usr/freebsd-dist/lib32.txz -C /mnt/crypt
  cp -Rp /mnt/crypt/boot /mnt/boot/
  echo geom_eli_load=YES >> /mnt/boot/boot/loader.conf
- vi /mnt/crypt/etc/fstab
  /dev/ada0s2.elib none swap sw 0 0
  /dev/ada0s2.elia /     ufs rw,multilabel,nosuid 1 1
  /dev/ada0s2.elid /var  ufs rw,multilabel,nosuid,noexec 2 2
  /dev/ada0s2.elie /tmp  ufs rw,multilabel,nosuid,noexec 2 2
  /dev/ada0s2.elif /home ufs rw,multilabel,nosuid 2 2
  /dev/ada0s2.elig /usr  ufs rw,multilabel,nosuid
- mkdir /mnt/boot/etc
- cp /mnt/crypt/etc/fstab /mnt/boot/etc/fstab

** Ports problem: unpacking .xz
Old /usr/bin/bsdtar don't know how to deal with .xz. Fix:
portmaster -d archivers/libarchive
ln -sf /usr/local/bin/bsdtar /usr/bin/tar  # <-- don't do this!
TAR=/usr/local/bin/bsdtar portmaster <whatever>  # <-- much better

And if .lzma is problematic (fbsd 8.x), install archivers/gtar.

* Internet in Portugal
In terms of Internet access over cell phone providers, we are very well
served. The best coverage is provided by a company called TMN, and they
have a "pay-as-you-go" option[0]. The equipment/modem is from Huawei,
which is also good for GNU/Linux support.

By using the product/service mentioned on [0] you also get a 1GB free
WiFi access on something called PTWIFI, which is a service provided to
TMN (and other companies) clients for free, with a very good coverage
as well.

Most car services, gas stations, food courts and known public places
have a PTWIFI hotspot. WiFi here is very common, and as far as security
is concerned, let's just say that my last wardriving session resulted
in ~3500 (this was just in my neighborhood) and from all those WAPs,
only 2 were using 802.1x (one of them was mine!).

** commiting stuff, [[gnus:nnimap%2Badb-centralen:INBOX#8639fi8ebc.fsf@shell.gmplib.org][Email from Torbjorn Granlund: Re: Double square brackets in ]]
Sedan gör man

  hg clone ~hg/gmp [[[foo]]]

och får då ett fint repository kallat [[[foo]]].  Tycker man inte om
namnet [[[foo]]], går det att byta till godtycklig sträng.

Sedan pillar min in önskade ändringar.  Med

  hg ci

checkar man in ändringarna i sitt repository.  Glöm inte att redigera
filen ChangeLog.  Vid incheckningen ska man skriva en kort kommentar,
varav första raden syns på hg-väbben.  Ofta är denna log kortare än den
man stoppar in i ChangeLog, ibland blir det samma .

För att knuffa in ändringen i ett annat repository, gör man

  hg push det-andra-repot

där det-andra-repot måste vara i sync med ens eget repo (annars gnäller
hg om att man håller på att skapa en gren).  Anger man inte argumentet
det-andra-repot knuffas ändringen till det repo från vilket man klonade.

Klart!  Man kan beundra sin webbberömmelse på http://gmplib.org:8000.

* bio, linus
[[Linus Nordberg|https://m.twitter.com/ln4711]] arbetar som programmerare
på [[NORDUnet|https://www.nordu.net/]] i Stockholm.  I arbetsuppgifterna
ingår utveckling och drift av ett flertal
[[Tor|https://torproject.org/]]-relaterade tjänster. Linus har nyligen
implementerat det första av flera steg för IPv6 i Tor. Övriga projekt
som håller Linus sysselsatt f.n. är
[[OTP|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/One_time_password]] för
[[Kerberos|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kerberos_(protocol)]],
[[http://software.uninett.no/radsecproxy/|radsecproxy]] och en
[[RadSec|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RadSec]]-klient för [[Project
Moonshot|http://project-moonshot.org/]].

Presentationen kommer att fokusera på varför anonymitetsnätverket
[[Tor|https://torproject.org/]] behövs men även förklara tekniken bakom. I
en tid när fler och fler stater begränsar sina medborgares tillgång
till internet fyller Tor-nätverket en viktig funktion för att
möjliggöra säker åtkomst till ocensurerad information och chansen att
göra sin röst hörd.  I en tid när gratistjänster på internet utgör en
allt större del av våra liv medan vi betalar med information om våra
internetvanor är verktyg som Tor ett skydd för den som själv vill
välja vilken information man delar med sig av.

** [[gnus:nnimap%2Badbc:INBOX.sent-mail.2012-09#yszzk4y9b36.fsf@nordberg.se][Email from Linus Nordberg: Re: Anonyma tips om brister i ]]
En riktigt tajt setup vore att sätta en busenkel, väl kodgranskad,
brutal-fuzzad webserver bakom Tor hidden services (HS) där man kunde
POST:a ett formulär. Det skulle kräva att användaren hade tillgång till
dator med Tor (eller CD/USB-sticka med Tails). 

En vinst med HS är att tjänsten blir svår att slå ut och att attackera
från någon annan vinkel än webservern. ssh, ntp,
programvaruuppdateringar, utgående system-status-mejl, avhämtning av
insamlat data -- allt det här kan man använda för att attackera tjänsten
och därigenom ev. avanonymisera källor.

En annan är att källan _måste_ köra Tor -- du som operatör av tjänsten
_kan_ inte råka få veta IP-adress som du kan råka läcka på ett eller
annat sätt. Detsamma gäller förstås alla hopp mellan källa och
tjänst. Men inte bara source-adress skyddas. Källan kör med största
sannolikhet Tor Browser Bundle som skyddar mot en massa attacker på
applikationsnivå. Källans browser kommer att vara mindre komprometterad
och i fallet Tails så kommer hela systemet att vara i bra mycket bättre
skick än godtycklig klientdator.


En slappare variant är ju vanlig slabbig lättcrackad webtjänst på ett
halvt opatchat Linux-system men som vägrar prata (http naturligtvis! men
också) med https-klienter som inte kommer från en Tor-exit. Tor kör en
reverse-dns-tjänst för snabbt svar på frågan "är den här addressen en
Tor-exit?". Sök på "tordnsel".


En totalt värdelös approach, till slut. Det här är väl vad man hamnar i
till slut för det mesta. Används kommunens vanliga webtjänster, något
ASP på nåt Windows bakom nån brandvägg, och skriv i POST-formuläret att
"Du kan naturligtvis vara anonym! Tänk på att inte tipsa om saker från
din ARBETSGIVARES dator om det är något jobbrelaterat!". Klart, bara att
fakturera. Glöm inte att använda ett utgånget certifikat bara, om du öht
skall ha något, och se till att det inte matchar DNS-namnet (tips: låt
din läcksajt heta något med "leaks" och skapa en underzon bara, men
skaffa inte separat cert, för tusan). Och inget jäkla redirect från
http -- för det första är det våldsamt dyyyyyrt med SSL och för det
andra så är det väl upp till användaren, va?.

** medlemsundersökning 2012
- Möten/seminarier irl, gärna delvis tillgängliga över nätet via ljud+bild-stream och/el IM (irc, jabber), sammanfattade i efterhand i text presenterad på web, uppmärksammat via mejlinglistor och twitter (före med tid och plats, efteråt med länkar till sammanfattning och diskussion). 
- Välj ut några frågor och driv dom genom att kombinera teknikkunnande och "policy-arbete"; ifrågasätt regelbundet vilka frågor som är viktigast och hur mycket inverkan man kan ha på dessa och välj därefter (cost/benefit) 
- Arbeta i projekt, gärna med utomstående personer och organisationer som bedöms hantera en fråga bättre / mer effektivt 
- Använd de resurser som finns -- pengar, kontakter, medlemmars vilja att arbeta för föreningen 
- Ta vara på medlemmar som vill aktivera sig!!! Det är i längden det enda en förening har. 
- Minimera formalismen ty den tar lätt död på arbetsglädjen (ett allmänt råd, inte specifikt för ISOC-SE -- jag har ingen aning om hur formella vi är)
* javascript / js
- javascript adds complexity to my browser, exposing the host to even
  more attack vectors -- executing arbitrary code in a very large and
  complex program seems like a bad idea

- the impact of somebody controlling any of the js libraries that
  almost every site pull these days (like apis.google.com) is scary

- using javascript to control the gui might fool the user into doing
  unwise things

- enables many tracking technologies -- noscript is a simple filter

i think that most people don't asses the risks as as high as i do and
that's fine

just as i shouldn't publish text only on facebook since i make it
inaccessible to non-fb users, i shouldn't publish text in a way that
requires javascript.

publishing a word document when a PDF would do the work is similarly
bad. publishing a PDF when ASCII would work is the same bad.

there are things that are hard or even impossible to do without
requiring the client to execute javascript. that's fine. rendering
plain text is not one of them though.
** other notes <2013-12-11 Wed>
Javascript seems to be an important part of how ad networks are tracking
web users. By disabling execution of Javascript the risk of having a
profile built should be lower.

The browser is probably the major attack vector into a personal computer
today. It's a monster when it comes to the amount of code it
carries. All code has bugs and some of those are exploitable. Cutting
out parsing and execution of a whole language lowers the complexity.

Downloading and executing code from whomever site owners decide are
needed increases the risk of running code that has been tampered with
for attacking the user. The user has no way of selecting whom to
trust. This is made worse by the quick pace at which web software is
developed (the chance of the code have being looked at is low) and the
fact that a few pieces of code is used in so many places (jquery would
be a sweet target for some malicious code).

There are others that are more about the software freedoms as expressed
by GNU but I won't go into those here.

** laundry scheme by andrea <2013-11-15 Fri>
speaking of bitcoin's anonymity properties, i've just devised a nice scheme to defeat things like
http://www.forbes.com/sites/kashmirhill/2013/11/13/sanitizing-bitcoin-coin-validation/                        
given a trusted counterparty with enough hashing power for solo mining
since miners can operate anonymously - through a hidden service even                                          
- and there's no way to link subsequent blocks from the same miner...                                         
you construct a transaction with zero outputs and the bitcoins to be                                          
laundered as inputs, and give it to the chosen miner rather than                                              
broadcasting it for any miner to pick up
then the miner can just include it in a block and claim the bitcoins                                          
as a transaction fee
and subsequently pay it back from mining profits on a future block,                                           
to different addresses in randomized amounts, etc.
the only way they could defeat that is if they treat all mining                                               
profits as 'dirty'

<teirdes> ln5: schelleken har fel eftersom han inte tar i beaktande

*** The bug is in ngx_http_close_request()
ngx_http_close_request(ngx_http_request_t *r, ngx_int_t rc)
/* ... */
    r->count--;

    if (r->count || r->blocked) {
        return;
    }
    /* ... */
    ngx_http_free_request(r, rc);

r->count is an eight bit bit field. It wraps from 255 to 0.
It seems like an attacker can make r->count++ happen.
Making r->count go to 257 will result in r->count being 1.
r->count-- will make it go to 0 while there are still 256
of something in use. The request will be freed by
ngx_http_free_request() though, and some other part of the code will
probably use freed memory. It doesn't seem impossible that this is
remotely exploitable.

An indication of someone exploiting your nginx would be that you found
"http request count is zero" in your log file -- a test for r->count
being zero is being done earlier in that function:

    if (r->count == 0) {
        ngx_log_error(NGX_LOG_ALERT, c->log, 0, "http request count is zero");
    }

but then sadly ignored.

** flashing
http://www.coreboot.org/Lenovo_x60x

flashrom -p internal -w coreboot.rom -c <third suggested, ends in 98D iirc>
*** web page content
     Patch flashrom to use RES1 SPI identification and spi_chip_write_1 for your flash chip, as well as change the flash chip model id to fit the RES1 command.

        Alternatively, you can copy the existing definition first as it is done in this patch. Choose either method: apply the patch in the link, or do the patch yourself, as per instruction below. 

        Find the definition of your flash chip in flashrom's flashchips.c
        Change the .probe field to probe_spi_res1
        Change the .model_id field to the RES1 ID given in the datasheet of the flash chip
        Change the .write field to spi_chip_write_1 
    Run flashrom -p internal -r factory.bin

        This step is IMPORTANT since the factory BIOS in your machine is tied to your particular system board (or "planar" in IBM FRU terms) with a unique ID not present in factory BIOS updates. 

    Run dd if=coreboot.rom of=top64k.bin bs=1 skip=$[$(stat -c %s coreboot.rom) - 0x10000] count=64k
    Run dd if=coreboot.rom bs=1 skip=$[$(stat -c %s coreboot.rom) - 0x20000] count=64k | hexdump

        Verify that the complete range is filled with ff bytes before proceeding! The above command must output: 
        0000000 ffff ffff ffff ffff ffff ffff ffff ffff 
        * 
        0010000 
        If this is not the case, the coreboot image needs to be rebuilt with the second-to-last 64kbyte block unused. 

    Run dd if=top64k.bin of=coreboot.rom bs=1 seek=$[$(stat -c %s coreboot.rom) - 0x20000] count=64k conv=notrunc
    Run bucts 1
7.  Run flashrom -p internal -w coreboot.rom

        This will be slow, it will output errors for addresses 0x0 and 0x1f0000 when working with a 2 Mbyte flash chip, and it will say "FAILED!" at the end, see Peter's mail before you panic. 

8.    Power cycle the machine (i.e. a cold boot, not just a reboot), now starting with coreboot
9.    Revert all changes made to flashrom (maybe backup the binary for later experiments)
10.   Run flashrom -p internal -w coreboot.rom.

        This will successfully overwrite the entire flash chip, including the last 64k that were write protected with the factory BIOS. 

11.   Run bucts 0

* x60
- That noise will go away with the kernel command line argument idle=halt 
  - update <2014-05-06 Tue> did that by editing /etc/default/grub:
    GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX="idle=halt" and running update-grub. A bit less
    noisy but hotter -- fan running a lot and temp around 45C. Or
    40/45 (Thermal 0/1) when on a good surface.
  - Update <2014-06-03 Tue> did that for real this time by running
    update-grub too (doh!). This time it went silence but the fan
    seems to be running constantly and temp is 45/57 (on a good
    surface) but climbing! Currently at 43/81 without loading the
    CPU. Estimated battery life time seems to go down to 2h30m from
    well over 5h IIRC. Note that I don't know what the actual battery
    life time is.
  - w/o idle=halt, temp is typically between 35 and 45 degrees for
    both values
- rmmod uhci_hcd removes the noise
  - Unfortunately this is the "USB Universal Host Controller Interface
    driver" which means that there is no USB when this is not loaded.
    Don't forget to load it again before locking the computer, if you
    depend on a yubikey to unlock.
- powertop, set all entries under "tunables" to "Good",
  in particular " Autosuspend for USB device [...]"
  (i.e. "echo 'auto' > '/sys/bus/usb/devices/4-2/power/control" but with
  the Kinesis attached, hmm i dunno -- the external keyboard stops working) 
  - This also lowers the power consumption according to
    http://www.coreboot.org/Lenovo_x60x

** trip report
Trip report, OpenITP Circumvention Tech Summit IV, Berlin Sep 29-Oct 1

About one hundred individuals gathered at hotel Ramada in Berlin
Sunday morning at 09:00 to sort out what is to be done in the field of
circumvention technology. This was the fourth CTS held by OpenITP and
was set up as an uncoference.

I had not before met most of the people in the room but there were
surprisingly many of which I knew or knew about. The whole thing was
led by an extremely energetic American called Gunner who does this for
a living. I've been gunnered before at Tor dev meetings and knew that
he's good.

After some ice breaking exercises we broke up in smaller groups, 3-15
people depending on interest, where we spent approximately an hour
discussing one topic. Report backs to the full group
afterwards. Follows highlights of a couple of sessions I was in.

The first day, I was in a session about malware and specifically how
we should detect that a computer has been infected and how to handle
it from there. Background for this is that the Syrian government,
amongst others, is known to have targeted people with malware in order
to own their computers. The outcome of the session includes shout outs
for running chrome books, use air gaps between systems, running only
signed software, push for document standards that are not turing
complete and the wish to make "blue team" a bit more appreciated
(today it's alledgely the red team members who gets to do all the
copulating). I object against most of what was said in that session.

The second day, Monday, included a session regarding standards
organisations, most notably IETF. How are standards being made and who
are the players taking part? There was discussion about the value of
having people from the circumvention tech community taking part in
standardisation. One of the outcomes of the session was that it'd be
interesting to know which companies and organisations are active in
the field. This information might be useful for funding people from
this community to go to IETF meetings, in an attempt to balance the
supposed over-representation of commercial and governmental interest.

Third day was a half day. I joined a session on the language used when
describing anonymity services. A common problem is that the word
"anonymity" means so many different things. Ana [more?] leading the
session presented a quick rundown of the academic definitions of
linkability, observability and [fixme] based on the work of [fixme]
and [fixme]. The group decided to try to encourage both users of and
providers of circumvention and anonymity services to try to describe
the anonymity properties of systems in terms of who and what is linked
to what by this or that observer. The session was made a bit more
concrete when we applied this on Tor. Not many people understand Tor.

All in all I'm afraid that this trip was not worth the time, mid
Saturday to late Wednesday including travel.

** Abstract
[[gnus:nnimap%2Badbc:INBOX#F1A58D9C-D004-4CDC-B107-8640BB7EB616@newamerica.net][Email from James Losey: Re: Encrypted]]
Crypto Explorers: Secure communication for the next generation

Secure communications is more than understanding what tools are
available but incorporationg encryption into a daily practice. But
while recent efforts have been focused at popularising the use of
encryption among curious adults or stressing the need with
professionals such as journalists we propose a new focus for the long
term adoption of secure communication: youth.

Crypto Explorers is an innovative approach to addressing this
opportunity. Incorporating the concept of leveling up in video games
and scouting initiatives, Crypto Explorers structures knowledge
sharing around levels of understanding of the risks, using tools for
securing communications, and sharing tools with friends and peer
communities. Spread across a series of key-levels the goals of Crypto
Explorers is to have participants walk away with practice skills for
using secure communicants, understand how to evaluate potential risks
and the value of one tool over another, and engage their peers on also
adopting similar practices.

Youth offer a compelling demographic as a focus for increasing for use
of encryption for everyday privacy and communication. Not only are
youth adept at adopting new technologies and naturally curious, they
are already avid internet users. The Pew Internet and American Life
projects finds that Internet adoption is highest with the 12-17 age
category at 95%, and nearly one in four are using a smart
phone. Additionally, through a survey conducted by the Berkman
Center’s Youth and Media Project, Pew also reports concern parents
have over their children’s privacy online. While yesterday's youth
might have experimented with submission crypto and other code games
the prevalence of smart phones provides a new opportunity to teach
youth lifelong skills for secure communications.

* Torifying gnus and erc using gnuls-cli
Instead of torsocks emacs I'd like to do SMTP, IMAP and IRC
"explicitly" by pointing gnus and erc at a socat running on and
binding to localhost. For example, this is how IMAP would be forwarded
over Tor:

  socat tcp-listen:9993,fork,reuseaddr socks4a:localhost:imap.adb-centralen.se:993,socksport=9050

Now, X509 certificate verification will not work since we point the
application to localhost but CNAME will be things like
imap.nordberg.se and the like.

I see a couple of solutions.

1. Configure application to run gnutls-cli with --insecure to avoid
   certificate validation.

   Not a good idea. Exit relay operators could MITM me and I wouldn't
   know.

2. Run gnutls-cli with --tofu and prepopulate the tofu store with the
   correct fingeprint prior to first use (--tacofu -- trust and
   confirm on first use?). TODO: Does --tofu already ask the user to
   confirm on first use? A: Yes. There's no need for --tacofu (damn!).

   One (small) drawback (for me) is that 2.12.20 (packaged in
   Debian 7) doesn't have --tofu.

3. Add --fingerprint to gnutls-cli, making it not verify CNAME but the
   server public key fingerprint instead.

pathname from group and nnmh-directory, using nnmail-group-pathname.

nnmh-directory is set to "~/Mail/".
group is sometimes "archive.sent..~", "delayed..~" and "drafts..~".

  nnmh-request-group("archive.sent..~" "" nil)

  nnoo-parent-function(nndraft nnmh-request-group ("archive.sent..~" "" nil))

** elevate.at 2013
http://2013.elevate.at/festival/ueber-das-festival/newsmagazin/detail/news/jacob-appelbaum-elevate-open-everything/

(Javascript only, so here's the text.)

Jacob Appelbaum
Jacob Appelbaum: Elevate Open Everything?

Freitag, 25 Oktober 2013
David Charles blogs about the events of the Elevate Festival.

Jacob Appelbaum has something to hide.
Jacob Appelbaum has acted as a spokesperson for Wikileaks.
Jacob Appelbaum identifies as bisexual.
Jacob Appelbaum has been detained twelve times by US government agencies.
Jacob Appelbaum enjoys photography.
Jacob Appelbaum is delivering this year's Elevate Festival Opening Speech.

An ordinary man, wearing black frame glasses over serious eyes, takes
the stage. He could be anyone: a coder from Silicon Alley, a
Shoreditch hipster-creative, a commercial architect from Berlin. His
anonymous post-millennial disguise suits his work on anonymity. He is
precise; the kind of precision that comes from believing that his work
is both serious and most often ignored.

Jacob Appelbaum begins by describing three aspects of openness that we
talk about in completely the wrong way.

1) Private information. What does that mean, when the state and other
   states and even private companies have complete access to your
   private information?

2) Data protection. Data doesn't need protecting. We shouldn't be
   talking about data protection, but people protection.

3) Terror. When we talk about terror, we should be afraid, not of a
   small set of people outside the group, but a small set of people
   inside. The greatest terror that has ever existed in Europe was
   made up of white Christians, not Muslims or any other external
   threat.

"We can't live in a post-privacy world until we live in a
post-privilege world," Jacob declares. Some people say that we are
living in a post-privacy world. What does that mean? Essentially it
means that privacy is dead. Or at the very least that privacy is a
hopeless case in this supremely connected world of instant data - and
that we should embrace that fact. We should throw open the doors to
our souls and bare all to all.

But Jacob has a different vision of post-privacy. "It's not privacy
that's died," he says, "it's liberty." He explains: "What we
previously called liberty, we now call privacy." Liberty is the
freedom of humans to look into their own minds and to decide how to
act in the world. Liberty is personal and private. Therefore, the
opening up of all that we call "private" to outside agencies, both
friendly and foul, will necessarily mean giving up our liberty, our
freedom to act based on private motivations.

"Who here was surprised when they heard that Angela Merkel's phone was
tapped by the US government?" The room drops a decibel of silence. "No
one?" Jacob scans the room. "No one. Why? Because knowledge is power,
so surprise means that you are admitting to not having that power. And
no one likes to admit to being weak."

If knowledge is power, then it follows that knowledge, like power,
will pool up around certain privileged groups of people. Those people
will stop at nothing to collect more and more knowledge and they will
do anything to stop others from getting knowledge of their own. Is
there a more fitting description of our security services? If they can
get away with it and if they can afford it, then the NSA will spy on
us.

So the point is not to stop them from doing what they exist to do, but
to make it politically and economically too expensive for them. "If we
don't take action," Jacob warns, "then serious action can be taken
against us and against those we love." He implores us to change the
world from one where whole population surveillance is the emergent
political phenomenon to one where it is used only against specific
targets. And we must do the same economically: whole population
surveillance is simply far too cheap to do in this networked age.

“So when people say, ‘I'm not surprised’, we should ask them a follow
up question: ‘Okay, when you're done being not surprised, do you have
any other feelings? Does that mean you approve?’”

And why should we care about the loss of privacy, the loss of liberty?
"Because once we lose this, our liberty, then we no longer have a
democracy, regardless of whether we still have a vote or not." Jacob
fixes us with that bespectacled seriousness. "Voting doesn't make a
democracy. The decisions taken by politicians come directly from the
security agencies - they just pick one of the options presented."

"The tin hat people," Jacob says, "the really paranoid people - well,
it turns out they weren't paranoid enough." It sounds like a joke, but
the only laughter in the cave is nervous.

Jacob ends with a very personal appeal. "If there's anything you can
do," he says, "to help get Ed Snowden asylum then please do it. There
is no single person in the world who understands all these systems
better and is willing to share that knowledge - at risk of his own
life - than Ed Snowden."

And there could not be a better example of the twin concepts of
privacy and liberty than a man denied the latter for exposing the
former.

** tor-internal <2013-11-01 Fri>
Subject: Open crypto hardware project

tl;dr Does Tor want to be part of an open hardware for crypto project?

Some IETF and ISOC people are trying to figure out how to get a
project going resulting in a "open-source hardware and software crypto
engine platform". The scope is totally unset at this point. There will
be some kind of announcement during the IETF88 week in Vancouver,
starting Monday.

People driving this are Randy Bush, Stephen Farrell, Lucy Lynch and
Leif Johansson. They try hard to make others in their communities
understand that this has to be done bottom-up rather than top-down,
i.e. this can not be run by any ones favourite organisation.

One community that this group needs input from and hopes for help from
is Tor. Do we want to be involved? I can see a wide variety of answers
to this, including "Absolutely!", "If they wanna drop us some dough
sure we'll take it." and "No way!".

I'm involved in this (with my NORDUnet hat on) because I believe that
development of trustworthy hardware is crucial and I'd like to
contribute to something that has potential to reach lots of people. I
worry equally much that the project gets taken over by a handful of
people influenced by dark forces (including personal gain) and that
the project limits itself to some for me uninteresting piece of
hierarchical equipment and standards (*cough* RPKI *cough*).


Here's an early draft of a statment and some notes circulating in a
small group, please take these texts with a pinch of salt (and don't
share, obviously):

--------------------
Hardware Open-Source Crypto  (HOSC) 
[[Better name needed]]

Recent revelations have called into question the integrity
of some of the implementations of basic cryptographic
functions and devices used to secure communications on the
Internet.  There are questions about some algorithms but
more particularly about implementations of algorithms in
software and hardware. The Internet community can and must
deal with these implementation issues. 

We therefore are embarking on the development of an
open-source hardware cryptographic engine that meets the
needs of high assurance Internet infrastructure systems
that use cryptography. The Hardware Open-Source Crypto
(HOSC) engine must be of general use to the broad Internet
community, covering the cryptographic needs for
applications such as secure email, web, DNS, PKIs, etc. 

For example, some key IETF protocols such as DNSSEC have a
need for a root key handling system in which the entire
Internet community can have confidence in the systems that
handle the DNSSEC root key. A system for that was developed
to ensure a high level of assurance that the private key
could not be abused without the collusion of a number of
trusted members of the community.  In the case of the RPKI,
there will be a similar need, though we are now operating
in an environment that requires far more scrutiny of the
operational environment as well as the cryptographic
hardware.  (Note that this is just one application, though
one that by itself could justify the development of HOSC.)

The HOSC project solicits functional, performance and
assurance requirements from a wide range of organizations
and will focus on the classic low level cryptographic
functions and primitives.  It is hoped that a group of
interested organizations will offer funding for
development, and that the IETF, academic cryptographers and
the Internet and open-source communities more generally
will provide advice and open and thorough review of
specifications and will contribute expertise to the
development of HOSC.

[[To enable the initial stages of the project to get
started, Initial funding of XXX for YYY has been committed
by ISOC.]]

The intent is that the resulting open-source hardware
cryptographic engine can be built by anyone with the
relevant skills and modest resources using widely available
components, public hardware specifications and open-source
firmware and software. It may be that some existing
open-source hardware and software are suited for HOSC, or
it may be that new board designs are needed, or both.

The initial work will be to further scope the overall
project and to create a set of requirements which we intend
to document in an Internet RFC that can form one
significant input on which the open-source activity can
build. An initial draft for that is at [[I-D-00]]

For more information visit: https://[[domain]]

The initial team who have commited to devote effort to make
HOSC a reality include:
--------------------

--------------------
open crypto hardware - technical project pieces

Recent revelations have called into question the integrity of some of
the implementations of basic cryptographic functions and devices used
to secure communications on the Internet.  There are serious questions
about algorithms and about implementations of those algorithms in
software and particularly hardware.

The algorithmic issues are in the domain of the heavy math cryptography
folk.  But we can must also deal with the implementation issues.  We
therefore are embarking on development of an open-source hardware
cryptographic engine that meets the needs of high assurance Internet
infrastructure systems that use cryptography.  The open-source hardware
cryptographic engine must be of general use to the broad Internet
community, covering needs such as secure email, web, DNS, PKIs, etc.

The project solicits functional requirements from a wide range of
organizations.  It will focus on the classic low level cryptographic
functions and primitives, and not get drawn into the complexity of
protocol layers caused by the lack of a coherent architecture.

It is hoped that a group of interested organizations will offer funding
for development, and that the IACR and public sector cryptographers will
provide algorithmic advice and wide and open review.

The intent is that the resulting open-source hardware cryptographic
engine can be built by anyone from public hardware specifications and
open-source firmware.  Anyone can then operate it without fees of any
kind.

** wiretapped on putting committments in the bitcoin blockchain
i found out recently it is actually cheap to put committments in the blockchain
using the homomorphic property of ecc keys
you take some thing you want to commit to, maybe a document or a merkle tree root 
and use the hash of it as a private key
you can combine keypairs to make new keys
with most ecc schemes
any 256bit number is a valid private key
you can add two public keys together and get a new public key
and add their private keys to get the new private key
so, say p1=pub(s1)
p2=pub(s2)
p1+p2 == pub(s1+s2)
so, say s2 is the hash of the thing you're comitting to
p1 is known
you can send money to p3 (=p1+p2)
and anyone can confirm s2 is part of it
(you publish p1 and s2)
