*** ndn report
I spent the time between Christmas and New Years at the 30th Chaos
Communication Congress [0] in Hamburg. This is the event of the year
for those who enjoy self organised events about computers and
networking, for many meanings of the word networking. We were over
10,000 attendees, including the "angels" volunteering to work with the
event in different ways.

I attended a silly amount of talks and work shops, some of which I
will mention here.

The opening event was followed by "Do You Think That's Funny?" by
lizvlx [1] where she presented some of the art projects she's been
doing online over the years. They all connect the internet with
pushing of limits. Quite interesting.

The same day, there was a Tor relay operators meeting where people
presented their organisations running exit relays. This was a valuable
chance to touch base with all the people in this field.

Still at day 0, I attended a meeting/workshop with Daniel
J. Bernstein, Christian Grothoff and more knowledgeable people on the
topic of decentralised services and "new interesting stuff". These
discussions moved too quickly into far future in my opinion. Still
interesting.

Next up, "Mobile network attack evolution" with Karsten Nohl
[2]. Karsten is presenting pretty much every year and it never gets
repetitive. He's plain madly good at what he's doing, digging into
mobile communication and proving how badly it is designed and
operated. Highly recommended.

Peter Stuge gave the talk "Hardening hardware and choosing
a #goodBIOS" [3] (in German but lots of good pics) about how to secure
a Lenovo X60 by opening it and apply soldering skills. Also don't miss
the Spiegel Online article [4] published the other day about this.

Glenn Greenwalds keynote [5] was presented over link at 19:30. Not much new in here.

Roger Dingledine and Jacob Appelbaum who many of you have met through
NORDUnet and SUNET activities presented "The Tor Network" [6] and
explained more about the state of Tor in the light of the Snowden
releases. I recommend anyone interested in computer or network
security to take a look at this.

I failed at going to "Baseband Exploitation in 2013" [7] by
Ralph-Phillip Weinmann and still have it on my to-watch list. RPW is
crazy skilled and well worth paying attention to IMO.

I could imagine some of you interested in Quinn Nortin and Eleanor
Saitta giving "No Neutral Ground in a Burning World" [8] too.

Most of my time after the Tor talk went into a long Q&A session where
about ten Tor people took on one group each answering questions about
Tor and discussing present and future development and deployment. I
led a group discussion about IPv6 which spilled into a longer workshop
the day after for relay operators.

How's that for a first day? Exhausting for sure. There were three more
days of much or less the same. Dropping links and some notes
below. Please let me know if you want more details on any of these.

Two things:
- Take a look at "The NSA's Spy Catalog" published by Spiegel Online
  and presented by Jacob Appelbaum on day 0x3
  http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/a-941262.html
- If you're interested in cryptography at all, make sure to watch "The
  Year in Crypto" with Nadia, djb and Tanja.

** XKEYSCORE
*** presentationen
- presentationen
  - är en informations/sälj-presentation om ett NSA-program som kallas
    XKeyscore
  - säger att global insamling av internettrafik sker
  - är hemligstämplad med "the five eyes" -- usa, england, kanada,
    australien och nya zeeland" -- som mottagare
- både passiva och aktiva attacker
- lyssnar på 150 ställen och lagrar allt, s.k. "full take" -- metadata
  och innehåll
- tre dygns lagring, indexerat på metadata
- exempel på saker man kan söka efter i databasen: epost-adresser,
  telefonnummer, inloggningar, filnamn, vänlistor, dator-fingerprint
  (s. 12), url:ar (i.e. vad folk googlar på), referer header (var folk
  kommer ifrån)
- exempel på saker man kan hitta: ngn använder krypto, ngn pratar ett
  språk som inte är vanligt i det området, ngn söker efter "skumma
  grejer", alla krypterade word-dokument från Iran, all användning av
  PGP i Iran
- exempel på fler saker: "visa mig alla VPN-uppkopplingsförsök i land
  X så att jag kan dekryptera dom och upptäcka alla användare" (s. 17)
- metadata lagras typiskt i 30 dagar
- man har ett dokument och kan spåra vem som skrev det och var
- "visa mig alla excell-blad från Irak som innehåller en MAC-adress"
- "visa mig alla maskiner i land X som vi kan ta kontroll över med
  hjälp av sårbarheter i koden"
  
- "DNI exploitation system/analytic framework" (DNI == digital network
  intelligence)

- letar efter anomalier -- användning av krypto
- TURMOIL/TURBULENCE är andra program som verkar gå mindre på djupet
- Marina verkar vara ett program för att göra [PSC] i efterhand
- Pinwale och Trafficthief är två andra relaterade program

- obs daterat feb 2008, för 5,5 år sedan

To generate a shared secret for TSIG:

    $ dnssec-keygen -a hmac-sha256 -b 256 -n HOST <name>

where <name> is a string. Suggested form for the name is

  <our-end>-<their-end>

For example

  adb-centralen.se-fatburen.org

Keys end up in a file on the form K<name>.<some-numbers>.key and .private.

RSA keygen should break things:
64-bit system sends modulo bits as 8 bytes, which is wrong for the
receiving 32-bit system.

pkcs11-tool:

  -l, --login                   Log into the token first
  -p, --pin <arg>               Supply User PIN on the command line (if used in scripts: careful!)
      --so-pin <arg>            Supply SO PIN on the command line (if used in scripts: careful!)

  -k, --keypairgen              Key pair generation
      --key-type <arg>          Specify the type and length of the key to create, for example rsa:1024 or EC:prime256v1

Run as root, for SoftHSM permission issues:

env PKCS11SPY=/usr/lib/softhsm/libsofthsm.so
PKCS11SPY_OUTPUT=/tmp/spy.log
PKCS11_PROXY_TLS_PSK_FILE=/home/linus/usr/src/pkcs11-proxy/psk.txt
PKCS11_DAEMON_SOCKET="tls://109.105.111.63:4444"
/home/linus/usr/src/pkcs11-proxy/pkcs11-daemon

** vt-d and vt-x
<joe> vt-d: d for "directed IO" (IBM POWER term, IBM was the first to have an
      IO MMU. feature is called IOMMU on AMD)
<joe> vt-x: virtualization eXtensions, or perhaps it's related to virtualized
      execution (pages being +x), not sure
<joe> so vt-x is the general thing that allows certain ASIDs to operate in
      ring 0 without accessing each other or the hypervisor (==run as a vm)
<joe> and vt-d allows you to "mmap" DMA access for PCI devices into specific
      VMs to prevent them from fucking over the entire machine.
<joe> why they can't be limited to the advertised DMA memory mapping range is
      a mystery to me, but intel didn't want it so.

* smtp privacy Received:
** modifying MUST and MUST NOT
> | If I were a particularly privacy-aware SMTP entity, would it make
> sense | for me to strip an incoming email of Received headers that
> were added by | others?  Or is that considered very rude?
> 
> I don't know how that'd be received. Simon, do you have an idea?

It would be a harder sell, but I like the idea and we should try to
come up with some wording that enables this.  The crux is that the
current draft modify the following MUST in RFC 5321:

   When an SMTP server receives a message for delivery or further
   processing, it MUST insert trace ("time stamp" or "Received")
   information at the beginning of the message content, as discussed in

Removing other Received headers would modify this MUST NOT:

   An Internet mail program MUST NOT change or delete a Received: line
   that was previously added to the message header section.  SMTP

So additional discussion is required.  I'm sure there would be
objections to this (breaking old protocols yadayada), but since the
purpose of the lines are primarily for debugging, I think those
objections aren't strong.  Unless someone can present a case for the
received headers actually provide some useful functionality.

* sjf & tor, winter 2015/2016
Projektet syftar till att reda ut de straffrättsliga aspekterna av att
driva en exitnod i anonymiseringsnätverket Tor. Nätverket används bland
annat av människorättskämpar, journalister och deras källor för att
anonymisera sin nättrafik.
För att bidra till kapaciteten i nätverket och för att öka säkerheten,
skulle det vara bra om fler drev noder. En faktor som är begränsande för
viljan att driva exitnoder är de juridiska aspekterna. Även mindre väl
sedd trafik utnyttjar Tors anonymitet, och om polis eller andra
brottsbekämpande myndigheter skulle intressera sig för trafiken är det
den som driver exitnoden som ”syns” utåt. Idag är det oklart vilka lagar
som träffar den som driver en exitnod, hur lagstiftningen ska tolkas och
vilket ansvar den som driver noden kan ha för den trafik som kommer
därifrån.
Genom att klargöra rättsläget hoppas vi kunna underlätta beslut om att
driva anonymiseringstjänster. Därmed bidrar projektet också till
möjligheten för människor att bibehålla anonymitet vid kommunikation och
informationsinhämtning på Internet.
Linus Nordberg skulle vara en värdefull resurs i projektet genom sin
kunskap om Tornätverket i allmänhet och genom sin erfarenhet som
operatör av Tornoder i synnerhet.

Som någon slags första approximation på arbetsinsatser från din sida,
och en grov tidplan som är med reservation för att jag inte pratat med
Paulina och Daniel ännu. Vad tror du?

- bidra till projektupplägget/bollplank - någon timme november - december
- kickoffmöte, presentation av Tornätverket och vilka rättsliga frågor
som en operatör kan möta. Januari. Förberedelse + möte ~ ett par timmar
- delta i referensgrupp och fungera som bollplank för juristerna. ~
några timmar utspridda under våren
- delta vid slutseminarium. ett par timmar i slutet av våren eller
tidigt i höst.

*** looking at the PP paper from nijmegen
- what's the problem it tries to solve?
  - a pupil goes to a school; the shool sends the pupil to a publisher
    of an e-book that the pupil shall read and interact with (UC2);
    the publisher wants to get paid (UC1); the school wants to receive
    feedback from the publisher (UC3)
  - as two addons, it presents solutions for pseudonymous attribute
    release and user inspection (of their own data)
- proposed solution
  - two central roles: key manager authority (KMA) and pseudonym
    facility (PF)
  - other parties: pupil, school and publisher
  - keys: yK = system-wide public key
  - data objects: PN = personal number; PP = PN encrypted in yK; EP =
    PP encrypted in key held by a given party (school, publisher)
  - PP and EP are randomizable, i.e. same content can have different
    look
- errata: missing a "not" in the sentence "The nature of the PF is
  more internet connected but does have particularly high availability
  requirements."
*** can we make a pseudonomy servers system (a la nymble) from this?
- two models: group signature (nymble, nymbler, bnymble) and TTP-free
  (BLAC, PEREA, FAUST, BLACR, PERM) (see [[file:p/dfri/dfri.org::*pseudonomy%20servers][pseudonomy servers]])
- what's the problem?
  - when all users look the same thanks to anonymity/pseudonymity,
    service providers can not hold users accountable for bad behaviour
  - a "revocable anonymity system" solves this by a TTP which can
    deanon a user
  - the primary problem is that of sybil resistance
- proposed solution
  - two lists: registered users ("whitelist") and banned users
    ("blacklist"), where registration has to be sybil safe too
  - authenticating user must prove she's registered but not banned, in
    zero-knowledge
  - associate each user with a scarce resource ("unique identifier"),
    like IP addresses, phone numbers, money, RAM, CPU
  - [more]
*** initial ideas, interests and contributions
- interest
  - pseudonymity service
  - [need more]
- contributions
  - network resources, network design and operational experience
  - access to id infrastructure, i.e. user base for PoC's
  - [need more]

* DDoS, ip stressers, booters
** tl@ on "the open booter data set" <2016-03-07 Mon>
The Open Booter Data Set Project

With the increase of denial of service attacks and pay-as-you-go
services labeled as stress testers or booters in the Internet,
critical services can be targeted with little technical knowledge. The
porpoise of our research is to publicly document how these services
operate including the technical analysis and description of the attack
vectors they exploit.

The research goals of this project include:

T1 Find the most active booters

T2 Document the attack vectors they advertise

T3 Collect and record attack data

T4 Measure their impact and performance

T5 Provide a technical analysis of how such malicious traffic is
created

T6 Provide signatures that help the development of low cost mitigation
strategies

* Umberto Eco on Ur-Fascism
[...] but I had also learned that freedom of speech means freedom from
rhetoric.

If we still think of the totalitarian governments that ruled Europe
before the Second World War we can easily say that it would be
difficult for them to reappear in the same form in different
historical circumstances.

Nevertheless, even though political regimes can be overthrown, and
ideologies can be criticized and disowned, behind a regime and its
ideology there is always a way of thinking and feeling, a group of
cultural habits, of obscure instincts and unfathomable drives. Is
there still another ghost stalking Europe (not to speak of other parts
of the world)?

In modern culture the scientific community praises disagreement as a
way to improve knowledge. For Ur-Fascism, disagreement is treason.

Besides, disagreement is a sign of diversity. Ur-Fascism grows up and
seeks for consensus by exploiting and exacerbating the natural fear of
difference. The first appeal of a fascist or prematurely fascist
movement is an appeal against the intruders. Thus Ur- Fascism is
racist by definition.

Thus at the root of the Ur-Fascist psychology there is the obsession
with a plot, possibly an international one. The followers must feel
besieged. The easiest way to solve the plot is the appeal to
xenophobia. But the plot must also come from the inside: Jews are
usually the best target because they have the advantage of being at
the same time inside and outside.

By contrast, the Ur-Fascist hero craves heroic death, advertised as
the best reward for a heroic life. The Ur-Fascist hero is impatient to
die. In his impatience, he more frequently sends other people to
death.

Wherever a politician casts doubt on the legitimacy of a parliament
because it no longer represents the Voice of the People, we can smell
Ur-Fascism.

Ur-Fascism speaks Newspeak.

All the Nazi or Fascist schoolbooks made use of an impoverished
vocabulary, and an elementary syntax, in order to limit the
instruments for complex and critical reasoning. But we must be ready
to identify other kinds of Newspeak, even if they take the apparently
innocent form of a popular talk show.

- Send an email to [Group Name]+subscribe@googlegroups.com
  - Tried the following addresses for the group

    - HardenedBSD-Users+subscribe@googlegroups.com
    - hardenedbsd.org+subscribe@googlegroups.com
    - hardenedbsd-org+subscribe@googlegroups.com
    - HardenedBSD+subscribe@googlegroups.com

to users+request@hardenedbsd.org. The reply pointed at
https://groups.google.com/a/hardenedbsd.org/group/users/subscribe
which redirects to
https://groups.google.com/a/hardenedbsd.org/forum/#!forum/users/join

Name]+unsubscribe@googlegroups.com.

bilder.nordberg.se
  - cat /jails/pics/usr/local/etc/letsencrypt.sh/config.sh | egrep -v '^(#| *$)'
CA="https://acme-v01.api.letsencrypt.org/directory"
LICENSE="https://letsencrypt.org/documents/LE-SA-v1.1.1-August-1-2016.pdf"
HOOK="${BASEDIR}/hook.sh"
CONTACT_EMAIL=hostmaster@adb-centralen.se
  - hook.sh
function deploy_cert {
    local DOMAIN="${1}" KEYFILE="${2}" CERTFILE="${3}" FULLCHAINFILE="${4}" CHAINFILE="${5}" TIMESTAMP="${6}"
    DEST=/usr/local/etc/lighttpd/certs/${DOMAIN}.pem
    cat $KEYFILE $CERTFILE $CHAINFILE > $DEST
    chmod 640 $DEST
    chown root:www $DEST
    DEST=/usr/local/etc/lighttpd/certs/le.pem
    cp $FULLCHAINFILE $DEST
    chmod 640 $DEST
    chown root:www $DEST
    service lighttpd restart
}
- how-to on jail 'web'
pkg install dehydrated
export CONTACT=hostmaster@adb-centralen.se
export CN=adb-centralen.se SAN=www.adb-centralen.se
cat /usr/local/etc/dehydrated/config.example | sed -e 's|#HOOK=|HOOK=${BASEDIR}/hook.sh|1' -e "s/#CONTACT_EMAIL=/CONTACT_EMAIL=${CONTACT}/1" > /usr/local/etc/dehydrated/config
cp /usr/local/etc/dehydrated/hook.sh.example /usr/local/etc/dehydrated/hook.sh
$EDITOR /usr/local/etc/dehydrated/hook.sh  # add deploy_cert() from 'pics'
chmod +x /usr/local/etc/dehydrated/hook.sh
echo $CN $SAN > /usr/local/etc/dehydrated/domains.txt
$EDITOR /usr/local/etc/lighttpd/modules.conf  # enable 'mod_alias'
$EDITOR /usr/local/etc/lighttpd/lighttpd.conf
  $SERVER["socket"] == <hostname:80>" {  # NOTE: http, not https
  ...
    $HTTP["url"] =~ "/.well-known/acme-challenge/(.*)" {
      alias.url += ( "/.well-known/acme-challenge/" => "/usr/local/www/dehydrated/" )
    }
  }
service lighttpd restart
dehydrated -c
sysrc -f /etc/periodic.conf weekly_dehydrated_enable=YES

cd /jails/le/usr/local/etc/dehydrated/certs
for c in sha512 sha256 sha1; do
  for f in */cert.pem; do
    echo -n "$f "; openssl x509 -fingerprint -${c} -noout -in ${f}; done; done

dnsrec=""

cat /usr/lib/systemd/user/dirmngr.service | sed -e 's/^ExecStart=.*/& --use-tor/1' | sudo dd of=/etc/systemd/user/dirmngr.service
systemctl --user daemon-reload
